title: Stocks Fall as Tariff Pause Fails to Quell Wall Street’s Worries
description: The stock market resumed its slide on Thursday, as the White House clarified that Chinese imports would face a tariff of 145 percent, prompting renewed investor angst over an escalating trade war between the world’s two largest economies.

title: Gerald Luss, Master of Midcentury-Modern Design, Dies at 98
description: Gerald Luss, whose sophisticated designs for Manhattan high-rise offices and lush layouts for residential interiors helped define the look known as midcentury modern — particularly his plan for the Time-Life offices, which was so true to its era that it provided the model for the sets of “Mad Men” — died on April 1 at his home in Manhattan. He was 98.

title: Andrew Tate Is Accused of Rape and Threatening a Woman With Gun in U.K. Lawsuit
description: Andrew Tate, the online influencer known for his misogynistic views, has been accused of raping two women and threatening one of them with a gun, in a claim filed in Britain’s High Court.

title: Trump May Seek Judicial Oversight of Columbia, Potentially for Years
description: The Trump administration may seek to have a federal judge enforce any deal it reaches with Columbia University in an arrangement that could ensure that the White House has a hand in the school’s dealings for years to come, according to four people with knowledge of the matter.

title: ‘Her Majesty’ Is Glamorous and Salty Fun
description: The Spanish comedy “Her Majesty,” on Amazon Prime Video (in Spanish, with subtitles), is set within the fictional, scandal-plagued royal family of Spain. It centers on Princess Pilar (Anna Castillo), who probably should have outgrown her party-girl ways by now. She can be surly and resentful, and she isn’t as comfortable in the public eye as she’ll need to be. She’s no dummy: She knows she’ll be queen one day. But she has to step into the role much earlier than she expected.

title: Producing Something This Stupid Is the Achievement of a Lifetime
description: You might have seen the various data points suggesting that Americans are losing their ability to reason.

title: Friday Briefing: A Worsening Trade War
description: U.S. stocks tumbled yesterday as Treasury bonds began to sell off again, oil prices dropped and the stocks of Big Tech companies like Apple and Nvidia fell. Together, the signs pointed to a souring mood as investors assessed the worsening trade war with China.

title: Trump Close to Winning Concessions From More Law Firms
description: President Trump is planning to announce new deals with several of the nation’s top law firms requiring them to offer legal support for some of his favored causes, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Markets ‘Hanging on Every Little Bit of Tariff Talk’
description: Joe Rennison covers financial markets for The New York Times. He does not try to predict them.

title: If It Exists, Someone Has Left It in an Uber
description: It may surprise some to learn that New York is the most forgetful city when it comes to ride shares. So says Uber, which has released its ninth annual Lost & Found Index — a hilarious, surprising and occasionally gross list of stuff riders left behind in cars last year. (Miami, Chicago, Los Angeles and Washington, D.C., were close behind New York in obliviousness.)

title: Trump, Offering Few Details, Insists ‘Everybody’ Wants to Make a Deal With the U.S.
description: A day after President Trump capitulated on his global reciprocal tariffs, he and Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick insisted that one country after another was coming to them to make deals to avoid further economic pain.

title: Tariff Angst Rises
description: The exuberance that spread yesterday across Wall Street after President Trump dialed down his expansive tariffs did not last long. The U.S. stock market fell sharply today, with the S&P 500 down 3.5 percent.

title: Do You Receive Health Care at the V.A.? We’d Like to Hear from You.
description: The New York Times is working on a series of stories about the experiences of veterans seeking health care through the Department of Veterans Affairs. The United States has promised to care for those who served, and we would like to examine whether that promise is being upheld amid job cuts and other policy changes in Washington.

title: Dismissed Players Take Aim at New York Philharmonic Misconduct Inquiry
description: Two musicians who were fired by the New York Philharmonic filed amended complaints against the orchestra on Thursday that assert they were wrongfully dismissed and that an inquiry by the ensemble had been biased against them.

title: Boston’s Museum of Fine Arts Names Next Director
description: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston named Pierre Terjanian its next director and chief executive after a seven-month international search, museum officials said on Thursday.

title: In Cabinet Meeting, Musk Seems to Drastically Lower DOGE’s Savings Goal
description: While stumping for Donald J. Trump during the 2024 presidential campaign, Elon Musk said he could cut $2 trillion from the federal budget. After Mr. Trump took office and placed Mr. Musk in charge of the budget-slashing so-called Department of Government Efficiency, Mr. Musk lowered that projection by half, to $1 trillion in the upcoming fiscal year.

title: Phoenix Hits 100 Degrees as Southwest Swelters in Spring Heat
description: Phoenix hit a scorching 100 degrees Fahrenheit on Thursday, notching the city’s first triple-digit temperature of 2025 nearly a month before it typically reaches that high.

title: Joan Brown Campbell Dies at 93; Led Largest Ecumenical Body in U.S.
description: When Joan Campbell invited the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to speak at her all-white church in the Cleveland suburbs in 1965, she had no idea of the furor it would cause.

title: Michael Hurley, a Singer Both Eccentric and Inspirational, Dies at 83
description: Michael Hurley, a singer and songwriter whose music — an idiosyncratic kind of folk mixed with a variety of other styles — made him a revered elder to younger artists like Cat Power, Devendra Banhart and the band Yo La Tengo, died on April 1 in Portland, Ore. He was 83.

title: Trump Escalates Use of Official Power to Intimidate and Punish His Perceived Foes
description: President Trump’s first-term efforts to spur law enforcement officials to pursue his political enemies were haphazard, informal and often hashed out in private.

title: Stunt Design Will Be Honored at the Academy Awards
description: There will soon be a new category at the Oscars: achievement in stunt design.

title: E.P.A. Is Said to Plan Deep Cuts to Greenhouse Gas Reporting Program
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has ordered the virtual elimination of a 15-year-old federal program that requires thousands of power plants, oil refineries, cement factories and other large industrial facilities to publicly report their greenhouse gas emissions, according to two people briefed on the decision.

title: Supreme Court Sides With Wrongly Deported Migrant
description: The Supreme Court on Thursday instructed the government to take steps to return a Salvadoran migrant it had wrongly deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: Helicopters Pack New York’s Skies, Despite Years of Noise and Air Pollution Complaints
description: Every year, tens of thousands of tourist helicopter flights depart from heliports in and around New York City. These tours, which generally cost several hundred dollars, advertise seeing many of the city’s iconic sights from above — Central Park, One World Trade Center, the Statue of Liberty — in as little as 15 minutes.

title: More European Opera Houses Welcome Back Anna Netrebko

description: If you want to see your Korean friend revert to their childhood self, surprise them with a bowl of homemade jjajangmyeon.

title: Emergency Crews Respond to Small Plane Crash in Florida
description: Large plumes of smoke billowed into the air after a plane crashed in Boca Raton, Fla., on Friday morning.

title: Pope Makes Surprise Visit to St. Peter’s Basilica
description: Pope Francis made an unexpected visit to St. Peter’s Basilica on Thursday, wearing civilian clothes.

title: Pope Makes a Surprise Visit — and Style Statement — in St. Peter’s
description: For a pope known for unexpected gestures, Francis’ brief swing through St. Peter’s Basilica on Thursday might be the most audacious yet — at least in his attire.

title: May You Listen to ‘Interesting Times’
description: This week’s newsletter is a brief advertisement: As of this week, I have a new show, “Interesting Times,” with fresh episodes every Thursday, and I want to encourage you to subscribe.

title: Europe Moves to Shield Itself From Trade War Fallout
description: As the fallout from President Trump’s rewiring of global trade sets in across Europe, governments are putting in place billions of euros’ worth of “tariff shields” to protect their economies, companies and workers from uncertainty and the growing prospect of a recession.

title: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa Won’t Seek Re-election, Setting Up Open Race
description: Kim Reynolds, the Republican governor of Iowa, announced on Friday that she would not seek re-election in 2026, setting up the first open race for the state’s top office in years.

title: Review: Dance Theater of Harlem, Reshaped and Back at City Center
description: When Robert Garland was chosen to take over as the artistic director of Dance Theater of Harlem in 2023, it was the ultimate inside hire. After performing with the company for 13 years, he spent more than 20 as its resident choreographer and the director of its school. The choice seemed to promise continuity, and so far, continuity is what Garland has delivered.

title: What to Know About Who Pays the Higher Costs of Trump’s Tariffs
description: President Trump’s latest tariffs are about to become an unavoidable and expensive reality for American businesses and for people who rely on foreign goods.

title: Miami Art Dealer Is Charged With Selling Fraudulent Warhols
description: A Miami art dealer was indicted on charges that he sold fraudulent Andy Warhols to collectors and provided them with fake invoices and forged authentication documents to make them appear legitimate.

title: ‘This is Not Normal’: Trump’s Tariffs Upend the Bond Market
description: The bedrock of the financial system trembled this week, with government bond yields rising sharply as the chaotic rollout of tariffs shook investors’ faith in the pivotal role played by the United States in the financial system.

title: Trump’s New Way to Kill Regulations: Because I Say So
description: President Trump this week directed 10 federal agencies — including the Environmental Protection Agency, the Energy Department and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission — to implement a novel procedure to scrap a wide array of longstanding energy and environmental regulations.

title: Top U.S. Prosecutor in New Jersey, a Trump Loyalist, Targets Governor
description: The top federal prosecutor in New Jersey said she had directed lawyers in her office to investigate the state’s Democratic governor and attorney general over a statewide policy that limits how much help local police can provide federal immigration officers.

title: Song of the Week: Who Is Tate McRae?
description: The singer’s “Sports Car” is a hit, but why does it sound so familiar? Jon Caramanica explains from his car in the latest “Popcast” song of the week video.

title: Trump Administration Delays Plan to Limit Pricey Bandages
description: The Trump administration announced Friday it would delay the implementation of a Biden-era rule meant to restrict coverage of unproven and costly bandages known as skin substitutes.

title: Who’s In and Who’s Out at the Naval Academy’s Library?
description: Gone is “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings,” Maya Angelou’s transformative best-selling 1970 memoir chronicling her struggles with racism and trauma.

title: George Bell, Considered the Tallest Man in America, Dies at 67
description: George Bell, who at 7-foot-8-inches was called the tallest man in the United States, died on March 19 in Durham, N.C. He was 67.

title: What Is Actually the Point of Treating the N.I.H. Like This?
description: By the time their spending accounts were reactivated on Thursday, some scientists at the National Institutes of Health said they were running on fumes.

title: Fed Under Pressure as Inflation Expectations Surge
description: Federal Reserve officials have had one clear message since President Trump sharply escalated the global trade war this month. Keeping inflation expectations in check as price pressures rise is their No. 1 priority.

title: New York Helicopter Crash Recalls Another. And Another.
description: The helicopter has been a fixture in New York City for decades.

title: Alice Tan Ridley, Subway Singer on ‘America’s Got Talent,’ Dies at 72
description: Alice Tan Ridley, who rose to fame after decades singing for tips in the New York City subway with an unexpected run in the television show “America’s Got Talent,” died on March 25 in New York City. Ms. Ridley, who was the mother of the Oscar-nominated actress Gabourey Sidibe, was 72.

title: Ann Arbor Wants to Build Its Own Renewable-Energy Grid
description: The Climate Fix is our twice-a-month guide to the most important solutions to climate change across the world. Have comments about what we should cover? Email us at climateforward@nytimes.com.

title: Investors Seeking Safety Look to German Government Bonds
description: Germany has long taken flak from Wall Street and financial capitals around Europe for the extreme fiscal conservatism that has kept the country’s debt levels low. But as global markets convulsed this week, investors rewarded Germany’s caution by snapping up its government bonds, which are known as bunds.

title: Air Force Academy Stops Considering Class Diversity in Admissions Process
description: The Air Force Academy has stopped taking the race, gender or ethnicity of applicants into consideration, the Justice Department stated in a filing Friday responding to a lawsuit that accused the institution of discrimination for making class diversity a factor in its admissions process.

title: Pulp, Stereolab and Turnstile Return: Hear 10 New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes) and at Apple Music here, and sign up for The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

title: ‘Yellowjackets’ Season 3 Finale Recap: The Wilderness Is Hungry
description: We’ve made it back to the beginning of “Yellowjackets.”

title: White House Plan Calls for NOAA Research Programs to Be Dismantled
description: Trump administration officials are recommending the elimination of the scientific research division at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, according to internal documents obtained by The New York Times and several people with knowledge of the situation.

title: ‘The Great Gatsby’ Is 100, and as Fresh as Ever
description: A century after “The Great Gatsby” was first published, F. Scott Fitzgerald’s slender novel about a mysterious, lovelorn millionaire living and dying in a Long Island mansion has become among the most widely read American fictions — and also among the most analyzed and interpreted. As the Book Review’s A.O. Scott wrote in a recent essay about the book’s centennial: “What we think about Gatsby illuminates what we think about money, race, romance and history. How we imagine him has a lot to do with how we see ourselves.”

title: Justice Dept. Lobbies for Release of Ex-F.B.I. Informant Accused of Lying About Bidens
description: The Justice Department, in an abrupt reversal, asked a federal judge late Thursday to release a former F.B.I. informant from prison pending appeal of his conviction on charges that he peddled misleading claims seized on by Trump allies to falsely accuse the Biden family of taking bribes.

title: How Snow Becomes Deadly
description: This season, more than 20 people died in avalanches in the U.S. Can mountains be safer?

title: Con Artists Scamming London Tourists Meet Their Match: Batman and Robin
description: Batman and Robin have taken a break from fighting crime in Gotham City to swoop on low-level scammers swindling tourists in the center of London.

title: From ‘The Last of Us’ to ‘The Walking Dead,’ How Well Do You Know Your TV Zombies?
description: “The Last of Us” returns on Sunday, the latest in TV’s lumbering horde of zombie shows. Can you tell one from another?

title: Trump Will End Temporary Protections for Afghans and Cameroonians
description: The Trump administration will end temporary protections for more than 10,000 people from Afghanistan and Cameroon, putting them on track for deportation in May and June, Department of Homeland Security officials said on Friday.

title: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, April 12, 2025
description: Can you sort 8 historical events?

title: A Tragic End to a Helicopter Pilot’s New Adventure
description: “Living the dream.”

title: Stocks Post Gain for the Week, but Investors Remain Anxious
description: Stocks on Wall Street ended a volatile week with a bounce on Friday, while government bond markets continued to signal investor worry about the impact of new import taxes, as China raised its tariffs on American-made products to 125 percent.

title: Investigation Into Helicopter Crash Just Getting Underway
description: Recovery crews were searching on Friday for the scattered wreckage of a sightseeing helicopter that appeared to break apart over the Hudson River the previous day before slamming into the water, killing all six people on board.

title: People Flee Eastern Gaza City After New Israeli Evacuation Orders
description: Since the collapse of the cease-fire in March, Israel has issued a succession of evacuation orders across Gaza, covering roughly half of the territory, displacing thousands of Palestinians.

title: Kennedy Accuses F.D.A. of Drug Industry Influence That Barred Alternative Remedies
description: In a speech broadcast to the Food and Drug Administration’s Maryland campus on Friday morning, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. introduced himself as the nation’s health secretary with a meandering speech touching on everything from birds of prey to pollution in Lake Erie to the C.I.A.

title: Immigration Judge Rules Khalil Can Be Deported, but Legal Hurdles Remain
description: An immigration judge in Louisiana found on Friday that the Trump administration could deport Mahmoud Khalil, granting the government an early victory in its efforts to crack down on pro-Palestinian demonstrations on U.S. college campuses.

title: Elected Official Is Among Dozens Charged in a Mob-Linked Gambling Case
description: A local elected official is among nearly 40 people charged with racketeering and other crimes connected to an illegal gambling ring run by members of the Lucchese organized crime family, New Jersey’s attorney general said on Friday.

title: Five More Big Law Firms Reach Deals With Trump
description: Five more prominent law firms facing potential punitive action by President Trump reached deals on Friday with the White House to provide a total of $600 million in free legal services to causes supported by the president.

title: A President Obsessed With Water Pressure? On Netflix and in the White House.
description: This week, as the global economy struggled to adjust to whipsawing tariff policies, President Trump signed an executive order to address another national crisis: weak shower head pressure.

title: Suzanne Rand, Half of a Once-Popular Comedy Team, Dies at 75
description: Suzanne Rand, who worked with John Monteith in a comedy team that was often compared to the groundbreaking Mike Nichols and Elaine May — and that, like them, became the stars of a two-person Broadway show — died on April 2 in Manhattan. She was 75.

title: See the Moments Leading Up to the Nightclub Roof Collapse in Santo Domingo
description: Video taken at the scene shows debris was already falling from the ceiling of the Jet Set nightclub before it caved in.

title: Judge Declines to Block Immigration Enforcement Operations in Places of Worship
description: A federal judge on Friday declined to block the Trump administration from carrying out detention and deportation operations in houses of worship, finding that a coalition of more than two dozen religious organizations had not made a clear case that their spaces and congregants had become common targets.

title: A Judge Ordered the U.S. to Detail Its Efforts to Return a Deported Man
description: A federal judge in Maryland ordered the Trump administration today to provide daily updates about its progress toward returning a migrant, Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, who administration officials acknowledge was wrongly deported nearly a month ago to a notorious prison in El Salvador.

title: Rick Levine, Who Gave Commercials Cinematic Flair, Dies at 94
description: Rick Levine, an award-winning television commercial director who brought a big-screen sensibility to the small screen with widely celebrated spots, like a Diet Pepsi Super Bowl ad from the 1980s featuring Michael J. Fox risking life and limb for love, died on March 11 at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 94.

title: Mangione Says U.S. Bid to Execute Him Is an Instagram Stunt
description: Lawyers for Luigi Mangione asked a federal court on Friday to bar prosecutors from seeking the death penalty against him, arguing that Attorney General Pam Bondi’s recently announced decision to do so was “explicitly and unapologetically political.”

title: The 12 Best Things We Saw at Salone Del Mobile
description: This year’s Salone del Mobile furniture fair, which took place this week in Milan, fell much earlier in April than usual. But that didn’t spare visitors from the sneezing fits the city’s springtime pollen shed can bring — or from the long lines and late nights that are now part of the event, which in recent years has become even bigger than the city’s fashion week. There was plenty of chatter about how shifting tariffs might affect the industry but, in all other ways, the fair was business as usual, with big design brands launching new projects and fashion houses getting in on the action with homewares collections or — in some cases this year — surprising, experimental collaborations. Below, a dozen projects that stood out.

title: Thousands of Voters Must Verify Information in Contested Election, N.C. Supreme Court Rules
description: In the latest twist in a prolonged legal battle over a North Carolina judicial seat, the State Supreme Court ruled on Friday that thousands of voters must fix issues with their ballots or risk having them tossed. The decision partially upheld a lower-court ruling and could lead to the November election being overturned.

title: My Girlfriend Keeps Looking Through My Phone. Should We Break Up?
description: I’m a 60-year-old man who has been divorced for eight years now. Since my divorce, I have not remarried and have ended two significant relationships because of behavioral and substance-use issues. Currently I’m in a relationship of 16 months with a recently separated woman. We don’t live together, but we spend most of our time together, functioning like a married couple. I’m employed in a higher-paying job and cover most of our expenses. When things are good, the relationship is deeply fulfilling and our romantic life is exceptional.

title: Joseph Boskin, Scholar of Humor and April Fools’ Prankster, Dies at 95
description: In March of 1983, a public relations official at Boston University asked Joseph Boskin, a scholar of humor in the history department, whether he knew anything about the origin of April Fools’ Day.

title: F.B.I. Suspends Employee on Patel’s So-Called Enemies List
description: The F.B.I. has suspended an analyst on Kash Patel’s so-called enemies list after Mr. Patel told lawmakers that the bureau under his leadership would stay out of the political fray and not punish employees for partisan reasons.

title: South Carolina Executes Second Inmate by Firing Squad
description: South Carolina executed another convicted murderer by firing squad on Friday night, the second such execution in the state.

title: Education Department Is Threatening to Cut All Federal Funding for Maine Schools
description: The Department of Education said on Friday that it was moving to cut off all federal funding for Maine’s public schools because the state had ignored President Trump’s executive order banning transgender athletes from girls’ sports teams.

title: Soulja Boy Is Ordered to Pay $4 Million in Sexual Assault Case
description: A jury in Los Angeles found the rapper Soulja Boy liable for sexual battery and assault, ordering him to pay $4 million to a woman who said that he became violent toward her as their once-professional relationship turned romantic, the woman’s lawyer said.

title: Military Judge Throws Out Sept. 11 Case Confession as Obtained Through Torture
description: A military judge on Friday threw out the confession that a man accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks made to federal agents in 2007 at Guantánamo Bay, ruling the statements were the product of a campaign of torture and isolation carried out by the C.I.A.

title: Pennsylvania Man Threatened to Kill Trump and Musk, U.S. Says
description: A Pennsylvania man was arrested this week after the authorities said he threatened to assassinate President Trump, Elon Musk and other government officials in comments that he posted on YouTube.

title: A New Policy Points Up a Musk Obsession
description: One hallmark of Elon Musk’s 12 weeks in government has been his focus on Social Security.

title: Freed From Prison by Trump and Now Facing the Prospect of Going Back
description: In the early hours of Feb. 15, Jonathan Braun, a violent felon granted clemency by President Trump, was agitated.

title: Efforts to Resentence Menendez Brothers Can Proceed, Judge Says
description: An effort to resentence the Menendez brothers can proceed after a Los Angeles judge cleared the way Friday for additional hearings next week.

title: Judge Says One DOGE Member Can Access Sensitive Treasury Dept. Data
description: A Manhattan federal judge ruled on Friday that one member of Elon Musk’s government efficiency program could have access to sensitive payment and data systems at the Treasury Department, as long as that person goes through appropriate training and files disclosures.

title: Get on the Board
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is a witty challenge from Jesse Cohn, who constructed two Friday grids for The Times last year (in the spring and the fall). Both were themeless, but Mr. Cohn also has a knack for interesting little patterns — mirrored entries with comedy in common, for example, or intersecting clues that involve scary animal sounds (or much scarier nukes). There are a lot of culinary elements in the puzzle as well, and I’m sure that solvers will notice other convergences.

title: Trump Directive Calls to Turn Border Land Into ‘Military Installation’
description: President Trump announced a plan on Friday to turn a narrow strip along the Mexican border in California, Arizona and New Mexico into a military installation as part of his effort to curtail illegal crossings.

title: White House Moves Obama Portrait to Make Room for New One of Trump
description: The Trump administration said on Friday that it had moved a portrait of former President Barack Obama in a White House hallway and replaced it with a pop-art painting of President Trump pumping his fist after the assassination attempt last year on the campaign trail in Butler, Pa.

title: Corrections: April 12, 2025
description: An article on Tuesday about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s plans for the Indian Health Service misattributed a quote about Native Americans as political minorities. It was said by a Native leader who requested anonymity, not David Simmons, the government affairs and advocacy director for the National Indian Child Welfare Association.

title: After L.A. Fires, Edison Wants to Bury Power Lines in Altadena and Malibu
description: Southern California Edison, the electric utility whose equipment has been the focus of investigations into the deadly Eaton fire in Los Angeles County in January, said on Friday that it planned to bury more than 150 miles of power lines in fire-prone areas near Altadena and Malibu, Calif.

title: Appeals Court Scales Back Freeze on Firing Consumer Bureau Employees
description: A federal appeals panel on Friday halted parts of a district court judge’s injunction blocking the Trump administration’s effort to dismantle the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, allowing officials to move ahead with firing some agency employees.

title: Quote of the Day: No-Nonsense Heiress Leading New York’s Police
description: “Go out and fill out the hurt feelings report and leave it in the file. It’s called having a boss.”

title: Coup Leader Is Favored in Gabon Election After Ruling Family’s Fall
description: Voters in Gabon are set to pick their next president on Saturday, and on paper they have plenty of options: anti-French firebrands, a general who staged a coup, a tax inspector and a female candidate in this oil-rich Central African country.

title: Boeing Helped Power Russia’s Economy. Could It Return?
description: To hear President Vladimir V. Putin tell it, Russia’s economy has thrived despite Western sanctions, becoming more self-sufficient and reorienting toward new markets.

title: What to Know About U.S. Talks With Iran Over Its Nuclear Program
description: A brief handshake may be the most likely outcome from preliminary diplomatic talks set for Saturday between American and Iranian officials.

title: For Taiwan’s Small Exporters, the Uncertainty’s as Bad as the Tariffs
description: Since President Trump announced his wave of globe-spanning tariffs, Alex Tang has held morning pep talks with the dozen or so workers at his lathe-making factory in central Taiwan, preparing them for rocky times ahead. His business, like all of Taiwan’s export-dependent manufacturers, could be hit hard.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.

title: How an American Sign Language Artist Spends Their Sundays
description: Brandon Kazen-Maddox has always felt an affinity with mermaids.

title: After Police Chase and Fiery Crash, an Agonizing Wait to Learn the Worst
description: Carmen Colon felt a sense of dread when her stepson did not respond to her texts.

title: Endorsement by Mayor Adams Appears to Lift Sales of Kash Patel’s Book
description: As mayor of New York City, Eric Adams faces uncertain re-election prospects this year. Should all not go according to plan, he may want to try his hand as a book promoter.

title: Before a Fatal Helicopter Crash, 2 Midair Breakdowns and Unpaid Bills
description: As federal investigators began the long job of examining what caused a sightseeing helicopter to crash into the Hudson River on Thursday, killing all six people on board, details began to emerge about the small company that made the doomed flight — and its operator’s checkered history.

title: Strong Winds Uproot Trees and Rattle Windows in Northern China
description: Beijing’s 22 million residents were asked to stay indoors on Saturday, as powerful winds swept across northern China. The winds toppled trees, disrupted travel and sports, and caused dust storms across the region.
